title: JEFF PRESTRIDGE: What on earth is going on at peer-to-peer lending group Funding Circle?
text:
What on earth is going on at Funding Circle, one of the country’s leading peer-to-peer lenders? Whichever way you look at this firm – either as an investor or customer (particularly sellers) – it looks like a business in crisis.

Floated on the UK stock market just over a year ago, the shares have tanked more than 70 per cent in value in the past 12 months in response to continued losses (£30.8 million in the first six months of this year).

Indeed, the company’s share price performance has been so appalling it has been jettisoned from the FTSE 250 Index. A closing share price of £1.06 on Friday compares with a flotation price in September last year of £4.40.

Funding Circle founder and chief executive Samir Desai

In August, co-founder and chief executive Samir Desai preferred (understandably) to gloss over some of the alarming financial numbers, instead talking about ‘strong repeat dynamics from borrowers’ (que?) and his aim to turn Funding Circle into the ‘world’s largest small business loans provider’.

An admirable aim – but mere words. ‘Small businesses remain underserved,’ Desai said (no problem with that statement, he’s dead right). ‘Our platform allows them to access the finance they need in a fast and affordable way, whilst at the same time opening up a stable and attractive asset class to a broad range of investors.’ (Here, I’m not so sure).

Seven years ago, I invested £200 with Funding Circle. I did it as a personal finance experiment – to see whether peer-to-peer lending passed muster as a new asset class, sitting somewhere between cash and shares on the risk scale.

On one level, I’ve done OK. My £200, invested across a broad range of businesses, has grown in value to £270.21.

There have been a few bad debts along the way – businesses failing, resulting in the loss of the money I’ve lent them and the stream of interest payments I was due – but I’ve done better than if I had stuck the £200 in a savings account with a high street bank.

But my £270.21 is not as accessible or attainable as I thought it would be. Far from it. Late last month, I thought I would sever my relationship with Funding Circle (experiment over) and put my money to use elsewhere (Premium Bonds).

Yet getting money back is like pulling teeth. I have two options.First, I can ‘turn off’ my lending and allow the business loans I have made to run their course.

This means I will receive my money back through a series of monthly repayments. But this will take forever – more than five years – and, of course, some of the loans could go bad in the meantime.

In other words, I may not get back £270.21. Alternatively, I can ask Funding Circle to find a buyer for my loans. The price for pursuing this route is that I will only receive an ‘estimated’ £246.72. Also, it could take four months or more before I get my money (this detail was only forthcoming after I pressed the company for it).

On Friday, Funding Circle told me it was looking to improve the way investors can access their funds. Too right it should be. At the moment, its business model does not treat sellers fairly. No wonder its share price remains in the doldrums.
